section.title: Comparatives and Superlatives
section.sectiontitle: For one or two syllable adjectives ending in -y, add -er for the comparative and -est for the superlative.
section.text1a: This church is older than it looks.
section.text2a: It is the oldest church in the country.
section.sectiontitle2: With short vowels (/I/, /e/, /Á/, /{/ ) double the consonant. If the adjective ends in -e, just add -r, -st.
section.text3a: This is the biggest city I've ever been to.
section.text4a: This room is larger than the dining room.

section.title: Comparatives and Superlatives
section.sectiontitle: If the adjective ends in -y, change it to -i.
section.text1a: The people here are much friendlier than I expected.
section.text2a: Maria is prettier than her sister.
section.sectiontitle2: For two syllable and longer adjectives, add more or less, the most or the least.
section.text3a: This software is much more useful.
section.text4a: This is the most dangerous city I know.

section.title: Comparatives and Superlatives
section.sectiontitle: There are some irregular adjectives, e.g. good, bad, far.
section.text1a: His new book is better than his last one.
section.text2a: It was the worst journey you can imagine.
section.sectiontitle2: If two things are the same, use as + adjective + as. For negative comparisons, use not as + adjective + as.
section.text3a: The train is as expensive as flying.
section.text4a: It's not as warm as last week.
